Introduction

Vulvovaginal candidiasis (VVC), commonly known as a yeast infection, is an inflammatory vulvar and vaginal infection caused by overgrowth of fungal Candida species, most commonly Candida albicans.  Although Candida spp. are part of the normal vaginal flora, overgrowth can lead to symptomatic infection.

Pathophysiology and risk factors



Candida fungal spp. are part of the normal vaginal flora and exist in balance with the predominant bacteria of the vaginal microbiome, gram-positive Lactobacillus spp.  Alterations in immune function or in the balance of the vaginal microbiome allow for excessive Candida proliferation.  Symptomatic infection develops when pseudohyphae invade the vaginal epithelium, leading to inflammation.  Disruptions in the flora balance can occur sporadically or as a result of well-known risk factors that predispose to candidiasis:



  • Antibiotic use reduces the number of lactobacilli, thereby disrupting the normal flora and allowing for unchecked Candida growth.
  • High estrogen levels (eg, pregnancy, postmenopausal estrogen therapy) increase glycogen content (used by Candida spp.) within vaginal epithelial cells.
  • Diabetes mellitus (and treatment with sodium-glucose cotransporter-2 inhibitors) results in elevated glucose, which facilitates adhesion of Candida to epithelial cells.
  • Immunosuppression (ie, HIV/AIDS, corticosteroid use) impairs regulation of Candida spp.  proliferation.


The majority of VVC cases are due to C albicans.  Therefore, this review article focuses on the presentation and management of C albicans as a cause of VVC.

Clinical presentation



VVC commonly presents with:



  • Vulvovaginal pruritus that can lead to excoriations.
  • Vaginal discharge (
    figure 1
    ), which is classically described as thick, white, cottage cheese–like discharge; however, this can vary in presentation to include scant, thin, or watery discharge.
  • Vulvovaginal inflammation with erythema and edema of the vulva and vaginal mucosa, leading to dysuria and dyspareunia.

Diagnosis and laboratory evaluation



Diagnosis of VVC is often made clinically with laboratory testing.  Physical examination often shows thick, white discharge with vulvar and vaginal erythema (

figure 2
).  Findings are most often confirmed using office-based tests that provide immediate results:



  • Microscopy with potassium hydroxide (KOH) wet mount preparation:  The KOH lyses epithelial cells to reveal budding yeast, pseudohyphae, and hyphae (
    image 1
    ).
  • Vaginal pH:  Normal pH ranges from 4.0 to 4.5.


Vaginal cultures can also be obtained; however, because Candida spp. are part of the normal vaginal flora, a positive culture does not always indicate infection.  Cultures are most commonly used for recurrent infection or treatment resistance.



Nucleic acid amplification testing for trichomoniasis, gonorrhea, and chlamydia is often performed because of the variability in vaginal discharge, particularly in patients with risk factors (eg, age <25, multiple sexual partners).

Differential diagnosis



The differential diagnosis of VVC can be tailored based on the presenting symptom of either vaginal discharge (typically infectious) or vulvovaginal inflammation.

Infectious causes



These causespresent with vaginal discharge (

figure 3
):



  • Bacterial vaginosis (BV):  is a common noninflammatory cause of vaginal discharge.  It is characterized by a thin, gray, malodorous discharge and fishy odor.  BV has a higher-than-normal vaginal pH (>4.5), clue cells on microscopy, and a positive whiff test (amine odor with KOH).
  • Trichomoniasis:  is a sexually transmitted inflammatory infection that presents with a frothy, yellow-green discharge, vaginal inflammation, and punctate hemorrhages on the vagina and/or cervix (ie, strawberry cervix).  Trichomonas vaginitis has a higher-than-normal vaginal pH (pH 5.0-6.0) and motile trichomonads on microscopy.

Autoimmune and allergic conditions



These conditions typically present with vulvovaginal inflammation:



  • Contact dermatitis:  often presents with itching and erythema due to reactions to irritants or allergies; however, there is often no accompanying vaginal discharge.
  • Vulvar lichen sclerosus (
    figure 4
    ):  is a chronic condition consisting of pruritus, sclerotic white patches, and progressive loss of vulvar architecture.  However, it most often is sparing of the vagina and discharge is not generally present.
  • Vulvar lichen simplex chronicus:  is a chronic skin disorder characterized by an itch-scratch cycle (scratching that initially relieves symptoms leads to more itching) most often caused by atopic dermatitis.  This leads to lichenification (thickened leather appearance) of the vulvar skin.  However, vaginal involvement and vaginal discharge are not present.

Management



The mainstay of VVC treatment is with oral or topical antifungals:



  • Fluconazole, which is the most commonly used oral treatment and generally requires only a single dose for complete symptom resolution
  • Intravaginal topical antifungals (eg, clotrimazole, miconazole)


Recurrent VVC (ie, ≥3 infections in 1 year) requires extended antifungal dosing, often with weekly maintenance therapy.  A broader work-up to identify and manage chronic risk factors (eg, diabetes mellitus, HIV) is also required.

Pregnancy considerations



VVC during pregnancy is not associated with adverse pregnancy outcomes (eg, preterm labor, preterm prelabor rupture of membranes); therefore, treatment is primarily indicated for symptom relief.  Because pregnancy is a high-estrogen state, the length of treatment may need to be extended compared to that in nonpregnant patients.



First-line therapy in pregnancy is with intravaginal topical azoles (eg, clotrimazole, miconazole) for 7-14 days.  Fluconazole is generally avoided, particularly in the first trimester, due to concerns for fetal malformation and increased risk for spontaneous abortions.

Prognosis



The prognosis for VVC is excellent because most cases resolve with antifungal therapy.  However, recurrent VVC (ie, ≥3 infections/year) is challenging and requires long-term maintenance therapy.

Summary



Vulvovaginal candidiasis is a common cause of inflammatory vulvovaginitis and is caused by an overgrowth of Candida spp., a normal component of the vaginal flora (

table 1
).  The diagnosis is made clinically with office-based testing (normal vaginal pH, yeast components on potassium hydroxide–prepared microscopy).  Treatment with antifungals (oral or topical) is highly effective.
